columns.text: The objective of this task is to explain which company is more likely to lease based on the tax bracket.

In previous exercises, we have learned that calculating the **Net Present Value** of a lease can have implications for both parties depending on each party's tax bracket. ***It is convenient for the lease that the tax bracket of the lessee is less than the tax bracket of the lessor***.

Also, we can see that: 

- It would be good for very profitable companies with a high tax bracket to apply the benefit of the depreciation and the interest tax shield. Therefore, it is in their interest to own assets that will be leased to other companies through **operating leases**.

- Low profitable companies with a low tax bracket will prefer to be lessees of **operating leases**, in which they will have no property obligations for the assets. In this way these companies also avoid the use of debt to dispose of the use of assets. 

As we can see, the benefits of leasing with interest as a key variable can also be interpreted from the perspective of the type of lease!

***Would finance leases have the same interpretation?*** 

By the way, we do not explain this case because we assume that a company with low profitability would not be interested in this type of lease.
